Award.AwardTitle: A mineral-physics based model of mantle electrical conductivity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many of the tectonic processes expressed at Earth's surface are the
manifestation of processes rooted deeper within the planet. Variations in
temperatures and composition of the upper mantle (the layer below the
crust) combined with the forces that drive motion contribute to the
deformation patterns at the surface and/or melt generation (possibly
resulting in volcanoes). Models of the mantle further our understanding
of the evolution of these processes, but these models require accurate
estimates of temperature and composition of the upper mantle---neither
of which can be measured directly. To estimate the state of the mantle,
geophysical models of a physical property sensitive to temperature and
composition are typically used as a proxy (e.g. seismic velocity and electrical
conductivity). Using electrical conductivity as a proxy requires
laboratory measurements on minerals at a range of conditions expected
for the mantle. Most interpretations of upper mantle
electrical conductivity are based only on the mineral olivine,
which comprises 60-70% of the mantle, and often ignore the possible
influence of the remaining mineral components. While olivine typically
dominates the electrical conductivity, there are cases, particularly
when bound water content is high, where electrical conductivity
contributions from orthopyroxene and clinopyroxene, the next most
abundant upper mantle minerals, may be disproportionate to their volume.
This project will involve the collection of electrical conductivity on
mantle pyroxenes in a laboratory controlled setting over a wide range of
physical conditions, leading to an improved model of dry pyroxene
conductivity. This model will help improve current,
and aid in future, interpretations of mantle conductivity models and the
processes that potentially drive melt generation and surface dynamics.
This project will also include the building of a conductivity apparatus
than can be used in future studies as well as the training of a postdoc.

There have been few electrical conductivity studies on orthopyroxene and
fewer on clinopyroxene. While they suggest anhydrous conductivity of
orthopyroxene is similar to that of olivine, with clinopyroxene about one
order of magnitude lower, they were conducted along predetermined oxygen
fugacity paths, thus limiting their application to specific conditions. This project
will focus on the collection of electrical conductivity and thermopower
measurements on mantle derived pyroxenes over a wide range of
temperatures and oxygen fugacities relevant to the mantle. By
collecting thermopower measurements in tandem with electrical
conductivity at several oxygen fugacity states and temperatures it
will be possible to estimate the concentration and mobility of the
various charge carriers and build point defect models that extend
conductivity estimates to a much larger range of mantle conditions. A
similar model for olivine has become a standard for comparison with
laboratory experiments and repeatedly verified in recent experiments.
In the past few years there has been a great deal of attention paid to
the effect of water on olivine conductivity. However, water partitioning
experiments show that pyroxenes may hold ten times as much bound H2O as
olivine. Apart from contributing to bulk composition, pyroxenites (rocks
with >50% pyroxene) are found regionally in veins which are important to
the geochemical budget, and may be responsible for the "garnet
signature" in mid-ocean ridges and ocean island basalts. If such veins
form interconnected networks they would have a disproportionate effect
on mantle conductivity. A reliable anhydrous pyroxene conductivity
model developed as part of this study will aid interpretation of future
electrical conductivity experiments on hydrous pyroxenes, as well as
improve the interpretation of mantle conductivities inferred from
electromagnetic sounding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have developed, built, and tested a laboratory apparatus to measure the electrical conductivity of rocks and minerals found in Earth's upper mantle, the part of Earth below the crust (which is 5-8 km thick in the oceans, 30-60 km thick for the continents) and above the transition zone (440 km deep).  This is important because we can independently estimate the electrical conductivity of the upper mantle using measurements of electric and magnetic fields at the surface, by magnetotelluric sounding (using portable equipment) and geomagnetic depth sounding (using data from magnetic observatories and satellites).  By comparing estimates of electrical conductivity made this way with measurements made in the laboratory we can estimate the temperature, water content, oxygen content, and amount of melting in the mantle.  This in turn helps us understand the mechanisms that create volcanoes, earthquakes, continents, and new oceanic lithosphere.

Electrical conductivity increases exponentially with temperature, and at mantle depths temperatures are between 600 and 1400°C, so our apparatus must heat the rock samples to high temperatures.  The apparatus operates at atmospheric pressure so that the chemistry of the minerals can be controlled using flowing gases (discussed below).  Without the pressures found in the deep Earth, rocks will start melting above about 1200°C, and so this is the highest temperature the new apparatus needs to create.  Heating is done with a custom designed, but commercially built, furnace. 

The minerals that make up mantle rocks contain iron, bonded to oxygen and silicon.  When heated, iron in mantle minerals can leave the minerals as metallic iron if there is insufficient oxygen in the experimental atmosphere, or hematite (iron oxide, or rust) if there is too much.  Once iron leaves a mineral it is stable as Fe (iron), FeO (wustite), Fe3O4 (magnetite), Fe2O3 (hematite) as the amount of oxygen increases and will not return to the mineral, which becomes permanently altered.  Not only does this mean that the sample is not longer the same as when it was in the mantle, but because iron controls the electrical conductivity of the mineral, measurements of conductivity will not be representative of the mantle.  This all means that when the sample is heated, the gas surrounding the sample must control the amount of oxygen available to the minerals.  Our apparatus achieves this with a mixture of carbon dioxide (CO2) and carbon monoxide (CO) flowing past the sample.   A given ratio of CO2 and CO is in equilibrium with a certain amount of oxygen (O2).  Too much oxygen, and CO will consume it by converting to CO2.  Too little, and CO2 will generate oxygen by converting to CO.  We call this an oxygen buffer, and in this way ensure that the sample remains the same as when it was in the mantle.

Furthermore, iron in mantle some minerals can exist in two oxidation states, with charge of +3 or +2 (Fe+++ or Fe++), and electrical conductivity increases with the amount of Fe+++ (the extra positive charge can "hop" from Fe+++ to Fe++).  Also, because iron in minerals often sits in the crystal lattice where magnesium (Mg++) normally resides, increasing Fe+++ creates holes, or vacancies, in the crystal lattice at magnesium sites, and these vacancies can move from Mg site to Mg site, which also moves charge through the crystal and again increases conductivity.  So, not only does the oxygen buffer keep the mantle minerals from altering to iron oxides, it also controls electrical conductivity within the stability field of the mineral.   The CO2/CO oxygen buffer is controlled by specialized mass flow controllers that provide calibrated ratios of gas to the furnace.  The new apparatus also has the ability to switch out CO with hydrogen (H2), which has a similar effect on oxygen buffering.  However, some hydrogen will enter the mineral, and in this way we can measure the impact of water on mantle electrical conductivity.  All the mass flow controllers are under computer control.
 
Finally, in a temperature gradient minerals will exhibit a thermoelectric effect, in which charges build up on the colder side of the sample.  We can measure this effect by moving the sample up and down the furnace using a computer controlled scissor jack.  Thermocouples on each side of the sample measure the temperature gradient as well as act as electrodes for measurements of conductivity and thermopower (these measurements are also carried out under computer control).  Conductivity depends on the number of charge carriers, but thermopower just depends on the number of carriers, so measurements of both can be used to make quantitative models of charged defects in mantle minerals.

The postdoc working on this project, Derrick Hasterok, developed skills to work with this type of instrumentation, and has taken up a lectureship at the University of Adelaide, where he was funded to build a similar apparatus there.
